keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY and LIZ ALDERMAN
byline.contributor: Nikolas Leontopoulos contributed reporting from Mytilene, and Dimitris Bounias from Piraeus, Greece.

lead_paragraph: Some 48 hours after the European Union reached a refugee deal with Turkey, Greek officials confronted widespread confusion about how to handle refugees.

headline.print_headline: Deal Appears to Curb Migrant Flow, but Greece Still Faces ‘Uphill Effort’
headline.main: Deal Appears to Curb Migrant Flow, but Greece Still Faces ‘Uphill Effort’

snippet: Some 48 hours after the European Union reached a refugee deal with Turkey, Greek officials confronted widespread confusion about how to handle refugees.
abstract: Greek officials are confused over how to handle refugees under terms of migrant accord between European Union and Turkey; Greece must provide provide shelter and food to migrants already inside country until their futures are sorted out, while at same time preparing for arrival of new refugees.
